text: Number 245, Milton Berman, Petitioner, versus United States.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
That was a fine Your Honor.
Well, that was because it was in the civil judgment docket.
All of the judgment was entered in the file of the criminal docket against this defendant on -- on or as of April 24.
That appears in the original record here, Your Honor.
When does the time for appeal start to run according to your -- your theory whether it's announced and opened -- a sentence then announced in open court or when it's -- it's --
-- from the weight of authority of this --

From the weight of authority of this Court and of the Circuit Court of Appeals, we would have doubts as to whether we could rely upon the April 25th docketing of the fine as giving us a right to appeal.
Oh, they take the sentence as it was given in Court, why does it make any witness when -- when it was docketed after that?

Because the -- the docketing -- if the metaphysical concept of entry of judgment is to be considered, the actual entry into the clerk's docket as of the time when the clock starts to run, then it may well be that if the Government or the Court chooses to enter the judgment as a money judgment as well as a criminal judgment that the fact that this is effective the following day, at least gives him the right to appeal from the money fine or the judgment insofar as it is a money fine.
Well, on what -- what authority do you rely of the fact that the fine was a civil judgment?
I -- I have no authority, Your Honor -- I --
Why do you call it something different then, from the -- in terms of imprisonment?
I would like to withdraw that.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
He could have reduced it to zero.
On the -- the rule does not provide for vacation, Your Honor.
Well, that he can do any time.
Well, I -- I'm -- I'm not sure that you and I are talking about the same thing.
I don't think it could be done in those terms.

Once that's done, I would assume, although I think it -- it would take some peculiar and unique circumstances to -- as a matter of fact, I would be surprised to find a judge merely entering a judgment of acquittal except in the case where the indictment, let's say, was absolutely invalid and --
-- and so that what you would get to eventually is that what -- what's happening in this kind of a case is that they got an illegal -- illegal sentence so there are a number of ways to get to this.
Well, as I say I think that there are ways that this can be done.
I have no question about its jurisdiction to do it if it's properly presented to him and I -- there's no --
I don't think that we've ever questioned this one.

Well, I'm not sure but I think it would arise in the same type of -- I -- I know of no case like this but I think that what you are talking about could arise in a type of proceeding that gives a judge jurisdiction power to grant a new trial.
Mr. Gilinsky, do you -- do you recall, I noticed the opinion doesn't indicate, what were the merits of Robinson's claim, were they constitutional?
There were no merits in -- in the -- in the case, Your Honor, because it arose on a notice of appeal.
You -- you see, one of the things I --
What happened there is that it was appealed --
It was -- it was a manslaughter case in the District of Columbia.
It was a murder case in which he got a manslaughter conviction.

Suppose this man had had no lawyer at all and he had not taken the appeal within 10 days, that's all that occurs, the court sends him, he had no lawyer, could the court have dismissed his appeal because he filed it late?
Well, I have to make two assumptions but I would say yes.
I'm -- but the reason I'm asking you is because the rule says --
Well, that's what I was going to explain.
-- (Voice Overlap) judge to take the appeal first.
So you'd be much better off without a lawyer, wouldn't you?
But if the lawyer -- but if --
-- he does have a lawyer and he suggests it, then he's out of luck.
Well, I don't think it's -- well, yes and no.
-- he can't get his constitutional question decided.
Well, I'm not sure that we're -- we're talking about the same thing.
Well, isn't there a constitutional question involved in this one?

Well, I -- we'd have to -- well, it's not as plausible -- possible but it -- it's -- it's not -- I mean, I suppose in any -- any time you say you have a search and seizure case, you have a constitutional question.
You may -- may be at a lose if you had a (Voice Overlap) --
Well, no, I don't -- not only lose.
You mean -- you mean -- suppose the record shows clearly that he had been denied his rights under the Fourth Amendment, do you think he could it attack collaterally?
Because of his lawyer's mistake here?
-- pose the question -- you pose the question of a -- of a clear violation of a constitution.
Well, when -- when we get through, if we dismissed that then, I will presume, this man could still raise the 2255 question.
I -- there is no -- there is no doubt in my mind.

So, Mr. Gilinsky, if that should happen, then I take it -- and the Government interposed -- well, he didn't take an appeal, then, the (Inaudible) problem would arise, wouldn't it, this 2255, whether or not he's fairly to take an appeal, denies them as it would not, perhaps, in a review of the state proceeding in a federal habeas corpus, the review of this constitutional question.
I -- we've had -- we've had the problem of people who have not taken appeals where constitutional issues are involved.
Even though you never attempted to face the issue.
That -- regardless of -- if you -- even if you'd taken an appeal, you could still go back, that's what I'm saying and even if it hadn't been raised on appeal.
Could you tell me about this.
It's on -- this is the original one.

First of all, I would like to call the attention of the Court to Folios 640 through 646 of the printed transcript of record in which the consideration of the defendant's desire to again appeal was raised orally upon the return of the motion and was discussed between the Court and counsel for both sides to eliminate any doubt as to that particular point.

It is our contention that with the second appeal, that in as much as it is a judgment of the District Court that the defendant contending that the illegal search and seizure was an element that entered into judgment even though it was a reduced sentence and a reduced fine.
It permits us to raise the point on one proceeding, the appeal in the Court of Appeals rather than to have to go down stairs all the way again and start going up.
That's the only difference, isn't it?
That is the only difference, a matter of judicial economy.
